key_points: U.S. Rep. Elissa Slotkin, D-Mich., announced plans to introduce a bill requiring secure firearm storage in homes with children.
The legislation is a response to the Nov. 30 Oxford High School shooting that left four students dead and others injured.
The proposed bill, named the "Safe Guns, Safe Kids Act," mandates gun owners to secure firearms if children could access them and imposes penalties for non-compliance.
Ethan Crumbley, 15, is the suspected shooter, with his parents being charged for supplying the gun used in the incident.
Slotkin emphasizes her background with firearms and asserts the law targets child safety, not infringing on the Second Amendment.
The law aims to protect children from firearm accidents in homes, incentivizing the use of gun locks or safes.
Slotkin seeks bipartisan support and endorsements from law enforcement, stressing the objective to keep children safe without political polarization.
James Crumbley allegedly purchased the 9mm Sig Sauer pistol used in the shooting as a Christmas gift for Ethan.
The Crumbleys' lawyers claim the gun was locked up at home, contradicting allegations of free accessibility to Ethan.
There was a significant increase in gun sales in 2020, and statistics show many children live in homes with loaded, unlocked firearms.
spokespersons: Shannon Smith and Mariell Lehman (Attorneys for the Crumbleys)
